messageBody:
Here I digress into more of a DBC-specific question, recognizing that
this is not a DBC mailing list...

javainsel wrote:
> Consider the examples at the JUnit site:
>
> Collection collection = new ArrayList();
> collection.add("itemA");
> assertEquals(1, collection.size());
> collection.add("itemB");
> assertEquals(2, collection.size());
>
> As a postcondition it would maybe look like "AFTER:size() ==
> BEFORE:size()++" (pseudo code). This is very readable, natural and
> of much greater use for testing and documenting than JUnit/TDD.

This "Contract" is actually not complete. Nor is the JUnit test.
Neither shows the expectation of what should happen when you re-add an
equal entry. I know how I'd do it with JUnit:

String entry = "itemA";
collection.add(entry);
assertEquals(1, collection.size());
collection.add(entry);
assertEquals(1, collection.size());
collection.add(new String(entry));
assertEquals(1, collection.size());

How would you capture that in a contract without re-implementing the
method itself? Something like this, I guess?

if ( collection.contains(obj) ) AFTER:size() == BEFORE.size()
else AFTER.size() == BEFORE.size()++;

Its just that I'm now starting to rewrite what's in the method itself as
part of the contract definition. Hence it seems that I'm dangerously
close to code duplication for one method.

NOTE: This isn't meant to question the value of DBC; I like what DBC
seems to offer. I just don't see how to write useable post-conditions
for non-trivial methods. And this case (Collection.add(Object)) is
actually a fairly trivial method.
